text-anchor='middle' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' fill='#f97316'>R</text></svg>
questions.solution:
Convert all to the same form or use the number line:
  Q = 0.08
  S = 0.25
  P = 0.4 (= 0.40)
  R = 0.7 (= 0.70)

Smallest to largest: 0.08, 0.25, 0.40, 0.70
‚Üí Q, S, P, R.

Answer: E.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests the student's ability to order decimals with different numbers of decimal places. The number line provides a visual scaffold, but the student must correctly locate each decimal to use it. A correct answer confirms secure understanding of decimal place value. The three D2 distractors each exploit a different 'whole-number thinking' variant applied to decimals.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: The student needs to compare four decimals with 1 or 2 decimal places. The key difficulty is that 0.4 > 0.08 despite '4 < 8' in whole-number terms ‚Äî the central place-value misconception. The number line reduces difficulty slightly (hence L2 not L3), but the question is harder than simple same-length comparisons.
design_rationale.number_choice: 0.4, 0.08, 0.7, 0.25 were chosen because (i) they have different numbers of decimal places (1 or 2), directly targeting the 'whole-number thinking' misconception, (ii) 0.08 is especially tricky (8 > 4 as digits, but 0.08 < 0.4), and (iii) all four fall between 0 and 1, keeping the number line clean and readable.
design_rationale.context_design: Number line from 0 to 1 (V4) with labelled tick marks at every 0.1. Points are colour-coded and clearly positioned. The visual support makes the task accessible at L2 while the mathematical content (decimal comparison) provides the test.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = whole-number thinking on digits (D2). B = partially correct but swaps middle pair (D2). C = descending order instead of ascending (D1). D = whole-number start with partial correction (D2).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student compares the digit strings after the decimal point as whole numbers: P‚Üí4, R‚Üí7, Q‚Üí8, S‚Üí25. Ascending order of 4, 7, 8, 25 gives P, R, Q, S. This is the classic 'whole-number thinking' misconception for decimals.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Treats digits after the decimal point as whole numbers ‚Äî compares 4, 7, 8, 25 instead of 0.4, 0.7, 0.08, 0.25.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly places Q (0.08) as smallest and R (0.7) as largest, but swaps P (0.4) and S (0.25) in the middle. The student thinks 0.4 < 0.25 because 4 < 25 ‚Äî applying whole-number logic only to the middle pair.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Partially applies whole-number thinking ‚Äî gets the extremes right but compares 0.4 and 0.25 by their digit strings (4 < 25).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly determines the order of all four decimals but writes them from largest to smallest (descending) instead of smallest to largest (ascending) as the question asks.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Misreads the direction ‚Äî orders from largest to smallest instead of smallest to largest.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student thinks P (0.4) is the smallest because it has the fewest significant digits after the decimal and 4 is a small number. Then orders Q (0.08), S (0.25), R (0.7) correctly within the remaining three. This reflects a 'shorter decimal = smaller value' heuristic.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Believes shorter decimals are always smaller ‚Äî a variant of the place-value misconception where the student assumes a 1-digit decimal is inherently less than a 2-digit decimal.

metadata.knowledge_point: A8 ‚Äî Function Machine (inverse: given output, find input)

questions.question_text:
A number is put into this function machine.
The output is 30.

What number was put in?
questions.diagram_description: A horizontal function machine flowchart reading left to right. A rounded box labelled '?' on the far left, followed by an arrow pointing right into a rectangular box labelled '√ó 3', followed by another arrow into a rectangular box labelled '+ 6', followed by a final arrow into a rounded box labelled '30'. All boxes have a light background; the operation boxes are tinted yellow and the input/output boxes are tinted blue.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 480√ó90. Four elements left to right: input rounded-rect (?) at x=10, operation-rect (√ó3) at x=130, operation-rect (+6) at x=260, output rounded-rect (30) at x=380. Arrows between each pair. Colours: input/output #bfdbfe, operations #fef3c7.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 480 90' width='480' height='90' font-family='Arial, sans-serif'><rect x='10' y='20' width='80' height='50' rx='20' fill='#bfdbfe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='50' y='52' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>?</text><line x1='90' y1='45' x2='128' y2='45' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arr16)'/><rect x='130' y='20' width='90' height='50' rx='6' fill='#fef3c7' stroke='#b45309' stroke-width='2'/><text x='175' y='52' text-anchor='middle' font-size='18' font-weight='bold' fill='#92400e'>√ó 3</text><line x1='220' y1='45' x2='258' y2='45' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arr16)'/><rect x='260' y='20' width='90' height='50' rx='6' fill='#fef3c7' stroke='#b45309' stroke-width='2'/><text x='305' y='52' text-anchor='middle' font-size='18' font-weight='bold' fill='#92400e'>+ 6</text><line x1='350' y1='45' x2='388' y2='45' stroke='#333' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arr16)'/><rect x='390' y='20' width='80' height='50' rx='20' fill='#bfdbfe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='430' y='52' text-anchor='middle' font-size='20' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>30</text><defs><marker id='arr16' markerWidth='8' markerHeight='6' refX='7' refY='3' orient='auto'><polygon points='0 0, 8 3, 0 6' fill='#333'/></marker></defs></svg>
questions.solution:
Work backwards from the output:
  Output = 30
  Undo '+ 6':  30 ‚àí 6 = 24
  Undo '√ó 3':  24 √∑ 3 = 8

The input was 8.

Check: 8 √ó 3 = 24, then 24 + 6 = 30. ‚úì

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests the student's ability to work backwards through a two-step function machine by applying inverse operations in reverse order. A correct answer shows the student can (1) identify that inverse operations are needed, (2) reverse the order of steps, and (3) apply subtraction and division correctly. Each distractor reveals a different breakdown in this reasoning chain.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Two inverse steps where the student must recognise that the operations must be undone in reverse order. This requires selecting a strategy (inverse operations) and executing it, fitting Apply √ó DOK1 (complex procedure) at L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: The machine is '√ó3 then +6' with output 30. This was chosen because (i) 30‚àí6=24 and 24√∑3=8 are both clean integer steps, (ii) the wrong-order inverse (30√∑3=10, 10‚àí6=4) also yields a clean integer ‚Äî creating a powerful D2 distractor, (iii) 30√∑3=10 is clean on its own (D2 for students who only undo one step), and (iv) the intermediate result 24 appears as option E (D3 trap).
design_rationale.context_design: Function machine flowchart (V6) ‚Äî a standard format in GL exams. The visual diagram (IS2) makes the two operations and their order explicit, while the inverse reasoning provides the cognitive challenge.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = wrong inverse order (D2); B = correct; C = only undoes √ó3 (D2); D = forward instead of inverse (D3); E = only undoes +6 (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student applies inverse operations but in the wrong order (same order as forward instead of reversed): divides by 3 first (30 √∑ 3 = 10), then subtracts 6 (10 ‚àí 6 = 4).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Applies inverse operations in forward order rather than reverse order ‚Äî does not understand that the last operation must be undone first.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student only reverses one operation: divides the output by 3 (30 √∑ 3 = 10) and stops, ignoring the +6 step entirely.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Only undoes the multiplication and ignores the second operation ‚Äî incomplete inverse reasoning.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student attempts to work backwards but applies forward operations to the output in a confused way: subtracts 6 (30 ‚àí 6 = 24), then divides by 2 instead of 3 (24 √∑ 2 = 12). Alternatively, the student computes (30 + 6) √∑ 3 = 36 √∑ 3 = 12 ‚Äî using addition (forward) instead of subtraction (inverse) for the +6 step.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses which inverse operation to apply ‚Äî adds instead of subtracting when undoing +6, or divides by the wrong number.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly performs the first inverse step (30 ‚àí 6 = 24) but stops here, presenting the intermediate result as the final answer. Forgets to also undo the √ó3 step.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Presents the intermediate result as the final answer ‚Äî completes only half the inverse process.

metadata.knowledge_point: M7 ‚Äî Money (calculating totals from a price list)
metadata.information_source: IS3 ‚Äî Complex data source (multi-row, multi-column price table)

questions.question_text:
The price list below shows the cost of snacks at a school fair.

Oscar buys 1 large popcorn, 2 small drinks and 1 small ice cream.

How much does he pay altogether?
questions.diagram_description:
A price table with 4 rows and 3 columns. The header row has three columns: 'Item', 'Small', 'Large'. The three data rows are:
  Popcorn: Small ¬£2.50, Large ¬£4.20
  Drink:   Small ¬£1.80, Large ¬£3.10
  Ice cream: Small ¬£1.50, Large ¬£2.40
All prices include the ¬£ sign. The table has a light blue header row and alternating white/light-grey data rows.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 360√ó170. Table with header at y=10, three data rows. Header fill #bfdbfe. Alternating rows #f8fafc and #fff. Text centred in cells.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 360 170' width='360' height='170' font-family='Arial, sans-serif' font-size='13'><rect width='360' height='170' fill='#fff' rx='4'/><rect x='10' y='10' width='340' height='30' rx='3' fill='#bfdbfe'/><text x='80' y='30' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>Item</text><text x='210' y='30' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>Small</text><text x='310' y='30' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>Large</text><line x1='10' y1='40' x2='350' y2='40' stroke='#93c5fd' stroke-width='1'/><rect x='10' y='40' width='340' height='32' fill='#f8fafc'/><text x='80' y='61' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>Popcorn</text><text x='210' y='61' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£2.50</text><text x='310' y='61' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£4.20</text><line x1='10' y1='72' x2='350' y2='72' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><rect x='10' y='72' width='340' height='32' fill='#fff'/><text x='80' y='93' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>Drink</text><text x='210' y='93' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£1.80</text><text x='310' y='93' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£3.10</text><line x1='10' y1='104' x2='350' y2='104' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><rect x='10' y='104' width='340' height='32' fill='#f8fafc'/><text x='80' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>Ice cream</text><text x='210' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£1.50</text><text x='310' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>¬£2.40</text><line x1='10' y1='136' x2='350' y2='136' stroke='#93c5fd' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='150' y1='10' x2='150' y2='136' stroke='#93c5fd' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='260' y1='10' x2='260' y2='136' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/></svg>
questions.solution:
From the price list, extract the correct size for each item:
  1 large popcorn  = ¬£4.20
  2 small drinks   = 2 √ó ¬£1.80 = ¬£3.60
  1 small ice cream = ¬£1.50

Total = ¬£4.20 + ¬£3.60 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£9.30.

Answer: ¬£9.30.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests the student's ability to (1) extract the correct prices from a multi-row, multi-column table by matching both item AND size, (2) multiply a unit price by a quantity, and (3) add multiple prices. A correct answer shows careful data extraction from a complex source (IS3) and accurate money arithmetic. Each distractor reveals a specific table-reading or arithmetic error.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Three items to price, one of which requires multiplication (2 drinks). The main challenge is navigating the table correctly ‚Äî choosing the right column (Small vs Large) for each item. This is Apply √ó DOK1 with added information-processing load (IPL3), appropriate for L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: Prices were chosen so that (i) small and large prices differ by enough to create meaningfully different totals, (ii) all intermediate and final sums are clean to 10p (no complex decimal arithmetic), (iii) each wrong-column or wrong-quantity error produces a distinct total, and (iv) the '2 small drinks' adds a multiplication step beyond simple addition.
design_rationale.context_design: School fair snack bar ‚Äî familiar to 10-11 year olds. The price list (V3) has two size columns, requiring the student to cross-reference item AND size (IS3, complex data source). QF6 table-extraction format.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = forgets to double drinks (D1); B = uses small popcorn (D3); C = forgets ice cream (D1); E = uses large drinks (D3).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads all correct prices but only counts 1 small drink instead of 2: ¬£4.20 + ¬£1.80 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£7.50.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the quantity '2' ‚Äî adds each item once regardless of the stated quantity.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads the Small column for popcorn (¬£2.50) instead of the Large column (¬£4.20), but reads drinks and ice cream correctly: ¬£2.50 + 2√ó¬£1.80 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£2.50 + ¬£3.60 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£7.60.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads the wrong column for one item ‚Äî picks Small popcorn when the question specifies Large.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student forgets to include the ice cream entirely: ¬£4.20 + 2√ó¬£1.80 = ¬£4.20 + ¬£3.60 = ¬£7.80.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Skips one item from the shopping list ‚Äî possibly loses track when extracting multiple items from the table.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads the Large column for drinks (¬£3.10) instead of the Small column (¬£1.80), but other items are correct: ¬£4.20 + 2√ó¬£3.10 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£4.20 + ¬£6.20 + ¬£1.50 = ¬£11.90.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads the wrong column for drinks ‚Äî picks Large drink price when the question specifies Small.

metadata.knowledge_point: N7 ‚Äî BODMAS / Order of Operations

questions.question_text:
Work out:

15 ‚àí 3 √ó 4 + 2
questions.solution:
Apply BODMAS ‚Äî multiplication first:
  3 √ó 4 = 12

Then left to right for addition and subtraction:
  15 ‚àí 12 + 2 = 3 + 2 = 5.

Answer: 5.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can apply BODMAS (order of operations) to a four-term expression with mixed multiplication, subtraction, and addition. A correct answer confirms the student gives multiplication priority over addition and subtraction, and then works left to right. Each distractor corresponds to a different misconception about operation priority.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: The expression has no brackets or exponents ‚Äî only √ó, ‚àí and +. The student must recognise that √ó comes first, then process ‚àí and + left to right. This is a standard L2 BODMAS question: one decision point (do √ó first) followed by straightforward arithmetic.
design_rationale.number_choice: 15 ‚àí 3 √ó 4 + 2 was chosen because (i) the correct answer (5) is small and unassuming, while several wrong paths produce larger, more 'obvious-looking' numbers ‚Äî testing whether the student trusts BODMAS over intuition, (ii) every wrong path yields a clean integer, and (iii) the expression mixes all three of +, ‚àí, √ó to test full BODMAS awareness.
design_rationale.context_design: Pure calculation (QF1) ‚Äî directly tests operation-order knowledge without contextual distractions.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: All four distractors are D2 (operation-order misconceptions): A = groups subtraction with addition before dealing with multiplication; B = strict left-to-right ignoring all priority; D = misreads √ó as + (or ignores √ó); E = does + first then √ó.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly computes 3 √ó 4 = 12 first, but then groups the remaining addition before subtraction: computes 12 + 2 = 14, then 15 ‚àí 14 = 1. Treats the expression as 15 ‚àí (12 + 2) instead of (15 ‚àí 12) + 2.
distractor_analysis.misconception: After handling multiplication, groups the remaining addition before subtraction ‚Äî does not apply left-to-right rule for same-priority operations.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student ignores operation priority entirely and works strictly left to right: (15 ‚àí 3) = 12, then 12 √ó 4 = 48, then 48 + 2 = 50.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores BODMAS completely ‚Äî processes all operations left to right regardless of priority.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student misreads the √ó symbol as + (or ignores the multiplication) and computes: 15 ‚àí 3 + 4 + 2 = 18.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Treats multiplication as addition ‚Äî either misreads the operator or does not understand that √ó produces a different result from +.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student adds before multiplying: computes 4 + 2 = 6 first, then 3 √ó 6 = 18, then 15 + 18 = 33... that gives 33 not 27. Alternative path: student computes 15 + 2 = 17, then 3 √ó 4 = 12, then 17 + 12 = 29... not 27 either. Let me recalculate: student does addition first (wrong priority): 15 ‚àí 3 = 12, then 12 + 2 = 14, then... no that path gives other values. Path to 27: student does √ó first correctly (3√ó4=12), then adds everything: 15 + 12 + 2 = 29... not 27. Hmm. Alternative: student misreads 15 as a different number. Actually: 15 + 3 √ó 4 + 2 = 15 + 12 + 2 = 29. Path to 27: student changes ‚àí to + and drops one term. Let me try: (15 ‚àí 3) √ó (4 + 2) = 12 √ó 6 = 72... no. What gives 27? 3 √ó (4 + 2) = 18, 18 + 15 = 33. Not 27. Try: 3 √ó 4 = 12, 15 + 12 = 27 (student ignores the +2 and changes ‚àí to +). That works: student does √ó first, but reads 15‚àí12 as 15+12 = 27 and ignores +2.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Performs multiplication first correctly, but then misreads the subtraction sign as addition (15 + 12 = 27) and ignores the final +2 term.

metadata.knowledge_point: G3 ‚Äî Angles (angles on a straight line / at a point)

questions.question_text:
Two straight lines cross at point O.

Angle a is 47¬∞.

What is the size of angle b?
questions.diagram_description: Two straight lines intersect at point O, forming four angles. Line 1 goes from bottom-left to upper-right at a steep angle. Line 2 goes from left to right with a slight upward slope. The four angles are: angle a (47¬∞, acute) in the upper-right region between the two lines, labelled in red with a small arc; angle b (133¬∞, obtuse) in the upper-left region, labelled in green with a small arc and a '?' marker. Point O is marked at the intersection.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 340√ó240. Two lines crossing at centre (170,120). Line 1 at 57¬∞ from horizontal (math coords), half-length 125. Line 2 at 10¬∞ from horizontal, half-length 148. Angle a = 47¬∞ between them. Arc radii: a=30px, b=28px. All coordinates computed by Python trigonometry and validated (offset < 0.5px).
questions.svg: <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 340 240" width="340" height="240" font-family="Arial, sans-serif"> <rect width="340" height="240" fill="#fff"/> <!-- Line 1 (steeper) --> <line x1="101.9" y1="224.8" x2="238.1" y2="15.2" stroke="#1e40af" stroke-width="2"/> <!-- Line 2 (nearly horizontal) --> <line x1="24.2" y1="145.7" x2="315.8" y2="94.3" stroke="#1e40af" stroke-width="2"/> <!-- Point O --> <circle cx="170" cy="120" r="3" fill="#1e40af"/> <text x="178" y="136" font-size="14" font-weight="bold" fill="#1e40af">O</text> <!-- Arc for angle a (47¬∞) --> <path d="M 186.3,94.8 A 30,30 0 0,1 199.5,114.8" fill="none" stroke="#dc2626" stroke-width="1.8"/> <text x="213.4" y="91.3" font-size="14" font-weight="bold" fill="#dc2626" text-anchor="middle">a = 47¬∞</text> <!-- Arc for angle b (133¬∞) --> <path d="M 142.4,124.9 A 28,28 0 0,1 185.2,96.5" fill="none" stroke="#16a34a" stroke-width="1.8"/> <text x="144.6" y="81.6" font-size="16" font-weight="bold" fill="#16a34a" text-anchor="middle">b</text> </svg>
questions.solution:
Angles a and b are adjacent angles on a straight line.
Angles on a straight line add up to 180¬∞.

b = 180¬∞ ‚àí 47¬∞ = 133¬∞.

Answer: 133¬∞.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can apply the rule 'angles on a straight line sum to 180¬∞' to find a missing angle. A correct answer shows the student can identify the relationship between adjacent angles at an intersection and compute the supplement. Each distractor targets a different misconception about angle relationships.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Single-step calculation (180¬∞ ‚àí 47¬∞) once the student identifies the correct angle fact. The identification step requires understanding which line the two angles lie on, but the diagram makes this relatively clear. Fits Apply √ó DOK1, appropriate for L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: 47¬∞ was chosen because (i) it is clearly acute, making the supplementary angle (133¬∞) clearly obtuse ‚Äî providing visual confirmation, (ii) 180¬∞ ‚àí 47¬∞ requires borrowing in the subtraction (good arithmetic practice), (iii) 47¬∞ is not a 'special' angle (like 30¬∞, 45¬∞, 60¬∞, 90¬∞) so the student cannot use memorised supplements and must calculate, and (iv) 2 √ó 47 = 94 provides a clean distractor.
design_rationale.context_design: Two intersecting lines (V1) ‚Äî the most basic angle-at-a-point diagram. Labels clearly indicate which angles are a and b. QF2 format with a geometric context.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A (correct) = 133¬∞; B = vertically opposite confusion (D2); C = right angle assumption (D2); D = doubling (D2); E = arithmetic error (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student confuses supplementary angles with vertically opposite angles. Vertically opposite angles are equal, so the student assumes b = a = 47¬∞. However, b is adjacent to a (supplementary), not opposite.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses supplementary (adjacent) angles with vertically opposite angles ‚Äî applies the wrong angle relationship.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student assumes that when two lines cross, all angles are somehow related to 90¬∞, or believes that intersecting lines always create right angles.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Assumes all intersecting lines are perpendicular, or that angles at a crossing are always 90¬∞.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student doubles the given angle: 47¬∞ √ó 2 = 94¬∞. This may come from a vague memory that 'angles come in pairs' or a confused attempt to use the vertically opposite rule by doubling.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Doubles the given angle ‚Äî a confused attempt at an angle relationship, possibly mixing up supplement with double.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student applies the correct rule (180¬∞ ‚àí 47¬∞) but makes an arithmetic error: computes 180 ‚àí 47 as 180 ‚àí 40 = 140, then 140 + 3 = 143 (adds instead of subtracting the units digit). Or miscalculates 80 ‚àí 47 = 43, giving 143 instead of 133.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Correct method but arithmetic error ‚Äî subtracts the tens correctly but handles the units incorrectly.

metadata.knowledge_point: S3 ‚Äî Mean (average) calculation

questions.question_text:
In a science quiz, Aisha completed 5 rounds.
Her scores were:

1,  2,  3,  6,  8

What is the mean of her scores?
questions.solution:
Step 1 ‚Äî Find the total:
  1 + 2 + 3 + 6 + 8 = 20

Step 2 ‚Äî Divide by the number of values:
  20 √∑ 5 = 4

The mean score is 4.

Answer: 4.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can calculate the mean of a small data set. A correct answer shows the student can (1) add all values correctly, and (2) divide by the number of values. Each distractor targets a specific confusion between mean and other statistical measures, or a procedural error in the calculation.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Two steps (add then divide). The addition is straightforward (single digits, sum = 20) and the division is clean (20 √∑ 5 = 4). The challenge is knowing the correct procedure for the mean. Fits Apply √ó DOK1, appropriate for L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: The five scores 1, 2, 3, 6, 8 were chosen because (i) their sum (20) divides cleanly by 5, giving an integer mean, (ii) the mean (4) differs from the median (3), the mode (no mode ‚Äî but closest misleading value is a small number), and the range (7), creating distinct distractor values, (iii) the scores are already nearly ordered (making it easy to spot the median for students who confuse mean and median), and (iv) all values are small enough for quick mental addition.
design_rationale.context_design: Science quiz scores ‚Äî a familiar assessment context for students. No visual needed; the data is small enough to present as a simple list (V0, IS1).
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = median (D2); B = divides by wrong count (D3); C = range (D2); D = sum without dividing (D3).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student finds the middle value of the ordered data set (1, 2, 3, 6, 8) and gives 3 ‚Äî the median ‚Äî instead of the mean.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses mean with median ‚Äî gives the middle value instead of calculating total √∑ count.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly sums to 20 but divides by 4 instead of 5: 20 √∑ 4 = 5. This may happen because the student miscounts the number of values (possibly counting the number of gaps between values rather than the values themselves).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Miscounts the number of data values ‚Äî divides by 4 instead of 5, a common off-by-one error in mean calculations.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 8 ‚àí 1 = 7, giving the range instead of the mean.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses mean with range ‚Äî subtracts the smallest from the largest instead of calculating total √∑ count.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly sums the five scores (1 + 2 + 3 + 6 + 8 = 20) but gives this total as the answer, forgetting to divide by the count.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Presents the sum as the mean ‚Äî completes Step 1 (addition) but omits Step 2 (division).

metadata.knowledge_point: F10 ‚Äî Percentage Calculation (finding a percentage of an amount, reduction)

questions.question_text:
A computer game normally costs ¬£40.
In a sale, the price is reduced by 15%.

What is the sale price?
questions.solution:
Step 1 ‚Äî Find 15% of ¬£40:
  10% of ¬£40 = ¬£4
  5% of ¬£40 = ¬£2
  15% = ¬£4 + ¬£2 = ¬£6

Step 2 ‚Äî Subtract from original price:
  ¬£40 ‚àí ¬£6 = ¬£34.

Answer: ¬£34.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can (1) calculate a non-standard percentage (15%) of an amount, and (2) subtract it from the original to find the sale price. A correct answer confirms the student can decompose 15% into 10%+5%, compute each, and perform the final subtraction. Each distractor isolates a different breakdown: giving the discount itself, subtracting the wrong number, using the wrong percentage, or applying the discount in the wrong direction.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Three sub-steps: calculate 10%, halve it for 5%, add them, then subtract. The percentage 15% is not a simple benchmark (like 10%, 25%, 50%), so the student must choose a decomposition strategy. This is Apply √ó DOK1 (complex procedure), appropriate for L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: ¬£40 and 15% were chosen because (i) 10% of ¬£40 = ¬£4 and 5% = ¬£2 are clean, keeping arithmetic manageable, (ii) 15% is not a 'standard' percentage students can recall instantly (unlike 25% = √∑4), requiring a strategic decomposition, and (iii) the sale price (¬£34) and discount (¬£6) are numerically distinct, preventing accidental correct answers.
design_rationale.context_design: Computer game sale ‚Äî engaging and familiar for 10‚Äì11 year olds. V0 because no visual is needed; all information is in the text (IS1).
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = discount amount only, not sale price (D2); B = subtracts percentage number from price (D1); D = uses 20% instead of 15% (D4); E = adds discount instead of subtracting (D2).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates 15% of ¬£40 = ¬£6 but gives the discount as the answer instead of subtracting it from the original price. Stops at the intermediate result.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses 'the discount' with 'the sale price' ‚Äî gives the amount reduced rather than the price after reduction.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student subtracts the number 15 directly from the price: ¬£40 ‚àí ¬£15 = ¬£25. Does not convert 15% into an amount first.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Treats the percentage number as a cash amount ‚Äî subtracts 15 (the percentage) rather than ¬£6 (15% of ¬£40).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student approximates 15% as 20% (perhaps confusing 15% with 1/5). 20% of ¬£40 = ¬£8. Sale price = ¬£40 ‚àí ¬£8 = ¬£32. The reasoning path is plausible (calculate a percentage, subtract) but the wrong percentage is used. The answer ¬£32 looks very reasonable and is close to the correct ¬£34.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses 15% with 20% (= 1/5) ‚Äî a systematic substitution error where the student uses a nearby benchmark percentage because they cannot decompose 15% correctly.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates 15% of ¬£40 = ¬£6 but adds it to the price instead of subtracting: ¬£40 + ¬£6 = ¬£46. Confuses 'reduced by' with 'increased by'.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Applies the percentage change in the wrong direction ‚Äî adds the discount instead of subtracting it.

metadata.knowledge_point: N9 ‚Äî Powers and Indices (square numbers, cube numbers, index notation)
metadata.format: QF4 ‚Äî Judgement / Verification (Which statement is correct?)

questions.question_text: Which of these statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Check each statement:
  A) 3¬≤ = 3 √ó 3 = 9, NOT 6 ‚úó
  B) 2‚Åµ = 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 = 32, NOT 10 ‚úó
  C) 4¬≥ = 4 √ó 4 √ó 4 = 64, NOT 12 ‚úó
  D) 5¬≤ = 5 √ó 5 = 25 ‚úì
  E) 6¬≤ = 6 √ó 6 = 36, NOT 12 ‚úó

Answer: D.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student understands index notation ‚Äî specifically that a‚Åø means 'multiply a by itself n times', NOT 'a multiplied by n'. A correct answer shows the student interprets indices correctly. Every wrong option is generated by the same misconception (a‚Åø = a √ó n), so selecting any wrong answer diagnoses the identical error.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: The student must evaluate five expressions, but only needs to recognise the correct interpretation of one to answer. The challenge is understanding what the index notation means. Fits Understand √ó DOK1 at L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: The five expressions were chosen to (i) cover both square (¬≤) and cube (¬≥) and a higher power (‚Åµ) to test general index understanding, (ii) ensure every wrong value is produced by the a√ón misconception ‚Äî making the error pattern crystal clear for diagnostic purposes, and (iii) ensure only one statement (5¬≤=25) is correct, since 25 happens to equal both 5¬≤ and 5√ó5 (coincidence between correct answer and the multiplication-check students might try).
design_rationale.context_design: Pure mathematical statements (V0, QF4). No context needed ‚Äî this directly tests notation understanding.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: All four distractors use the same misconception: interpreting a‚Åø as a√ón. This single-misconception design is intentional ‚Äî it creates a clean diagnostic: any wrong answer means the student has this specific misunderstanding.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student interprets 3¬≤ as 3 √ó 2 = 6 instead of 3 √ó 3 = 9.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads a‚Åø as a √ó n ‚Äî multiplies the base by the exponent instead of raising to a power.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student interprets 2‚Åµ as 2 √ó 5 = 10 instead of 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 √ó 2 = 32.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads a‚Åø as a √ó n ‚Äî multiplies the base by the exponent instead of raising to a power.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student interprets 4¬≥ as 4 √ó 3 = 12 instead of 4 √ó 4 √ó 4 = 64.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads a‚Åø as a √ó n ‚Äî multiplies the base by the exponent instead of raising to a power.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student interprets 6¬≤ as 6 √ó 2 = 12 instead of 6 √ó 6 = 36.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads a‚Åø as a √ó n ‚Äî multiplies the base by the exponent instead of raising to a power.

metadata.knowledge_point: M4 ‚Äî Area (rectangle)

questions.question_text:
A rectangular playground has a length of 12 m and a width of 5 m.

What is the area of the playground?
questions.diagram_description: A horizontal rectangle labelled with dimensions. The top side is labelled '12 m' and the right side is labelled '5 m'. The rectangle is shaded light green with a darker green outline. A small square in the bottom-left corner indicates a right angle. No grid is shown.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 320√ó200. Rectangle from (40,40) to (280,160), fill #d1fae5, stroke #16a34a, stroke-width 2. Top side label '12 m' centred. Right side label '5 m' centred vertically. Right-angle square marker at bottom-left corner.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 320 200' width='320' height='200' font-family='Arial, sans-serif'><rect width='320' height='200' fill='#fff'/><rect x='40' y='40' width='240' height='120' fill='#d1fae5' stroke='#16a34a' stroke-width='2.5'/><rect x='40' y='148' width='12' height='12' fill='none' stroke='#16a34a' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='160' y='30' text-anchor='middle' font-size='15' font-weight='bold' fill='#166534'>12 m</text><text x='296' y='106' text-anchor='start' font-size='15' font-weight='bold' fill='#166534'>5 m</text></svg>
questions.solution:
Area of a rectangle = length √ó width
  = 12 √ó 5
  = 60 m¬≤.

Answer: 60 m¬≤.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can calculate the area of a rectangle. A correct answer shows the student knows the area formula (length √ó width) and can apply it. The D3 distractors specifically test whether the student confuses area with perimeter ‚Äî the most common error in this topic area.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Single formula application (12 √ó 5 = 60), but the student must choose the correct formula (area vs perimeter) and apply the correct operation. The diagram provides clear dimensions. Fits Apply √ó DOK1 at L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: 12 m and 5 m were chosen because (i) 12 √ó 5 = 60 is easy to compute, keeping the difficulty in formula selection not arithmetic, (ii) the perimeter (34) and semi-perimeter (17) are clearly different from the area (60), making each error path produce a distinct answer, and (iii) 12 √ó 5 √∑ 2 = 30 provides a clean triangle-area distractor.
design_rationale.context_design: A rectangular playground ‚Äî a concrete, age-appropriate context. The labelled rectangle (V1) shows dimensions clearly. QF2 word problem format.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = perimeter (D3); B = correct area; C = semi-perimeter (D3); D = halved area/triangle formula (D2); E = doubled area (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student calculates the perimeter instead of the area: 2 √ó (12 + 5) = 2 √ó 17 = 34. Writes m¬≤ as the unit but computes perimeter.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses area with perimeter ‚Äî uses the perimeter formula (2l + 2w) when the question asks for area (l √ó w).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes l + w = 12 + 5 = 17. This is the semi-perimeter ‚Äî the student knows they should combine the two dimensions but adds instead of multiplying.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Adds length and width instead of multiplying ‚Äî confuses the operation needed for area with the first step of the perimeter formula.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 12 √ó 5 √∑ 2 = 30, applying the triangle area formula (¬Ω √ó base √ó height) to a rectangle.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Applies the triangle area formula (¬Ωbh) to a rectangle ‚Äî knows a formula involving base and height but selects the wrong one.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 2 √ó 12 √ó 5 = 120, perhaps confusing the perimeter formula structure with the area formula and including the factor of 2.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Doubles the area ‚Äî possibly conflating the '2' from the perimeter formula with the area calculation.

metadata.knowledge_point: N12 ‚Äî Estimation / M9 ‚Äî Sense of Measure

questions.question_text:
The picture shows a large bottle of milk from a supermarket.

About how much milk does it hold?
questions.diagram_description: A simple illustration of a standard large plastic milk bottle (the type found in UK supermarkets), with a handle on the right side and a screw cap on top. The bottle is coloured white/light blue. No measurement labels or scale are shown ‚Äî the student must use their real-world knowledge to estimate the capacity.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 160√ó240. Stylised milk bottle shape: wider rectangular body with rounded corners at bottom, tapering to a narrower neck, small rectangle cap on top. Handle on the right side as a curved path. Fill #e0f2fe (light blue), stroke #0369a1, stroke-width 2. Label 'MILK' on the body.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 160 240' width='160' height='240' font-family='Arial, sans-serif'><rect width='160' height='240' fill='#fff'/><path d='M 40,220 L 40,100 Q 40,80 50,70 L 55,40 Q 55,25 65,20 L 95,20 Q 105,25 105,40 L 110,70 Q 120,80 120,100 L 120,220 Q 120,230 110,230 L 50,230 Q 40,230 40,220 Z' fill='#e0f2fe' stroke='#0369a1' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='60' y='12' width='40' height='12' rx='3' fill='#0ea5e9' stroke='#0369a1' stroke-width='1.5'/><path d='M 120,90 Q 145,90 145,120 Q 145,150 120,150' fill='none' stroke='#0369a1' stroke-width='3' stroke-linecap='round'/><text x='80' y='160' text-anchor='middle' font-size='18' font-weight='bold' fill='#0369a1'>MILK</text></svg>
questions.solution:
A large bottle of milk from a UK supermarket typically holds about 2 litres (sometimes written as 2 pints for a medium or 4 pints for a large).

  20 ml ‚Äî far too small (that is about 1 tablespoon)
  200 ml ‚Äî a small glass of milk, not a large bottle
  20 litres ‚Äî a very large container, like a water cooler
  50 litres ‚Äî an enormous amount, like half a bathtub
  2 litres ‚Äî correct for a large supermarket milk bottle

Answer: 2 litres.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests the student's sense of real-world measures (ÈáèÊÑü) ‚Äî specifically capacity in litres and millilitres. No calculation is needed; the student must draw on everyday experience to judge which option is reasonable. A correct answer shows a secure sense of how much common containers hold. Wrong answers reveal systematic unit-scale confusion or lack of real-world experience.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: No computation ‚Äî pure estimation and common-sense judgement. However, the student must understand the relative sizes of ml and litres and have a mental benchmark for a milk bottle. Fits Understand √ó DOK1 at L2. The QF8 format ('about how much') signals that estimation is required.
design_rationale.number_choice: The five options span a wide range from 20 ml to 50 litres ‚Äî approximately 3 orders of magnitude. They were chosen so that (i) the correct answer (2 litres) sits in the middle of the range, not at an extreme, (ii) the two 'close' wrong answers (200 ml and 20 litres) are each exactly 10√ó off in opposite directions, testing whether students confuse litres and millilitres, and (iii) the extreme values (20 ml and 50 litres) test basic reasonableness.
design_rationale.context_design: A milk bottle (V7 real-world object) ‚Äî one of the most familiar capacity references for UK children. The SVG illustration helps the student visualise the actual object. QF8 estimation format.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = extreme underestimate (D1); B = √∑10 (D2); C = √ó10 (D2); D = extreme overestimate (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student has very poor sense of capacity scales ‚Äî 20 ml is about one tablespoon. This represents a wild underestimate showing no benchmark for liquid measures.
distractor_analysis.misconception: No practical sense of millilitre scale ‚Äî does not recognise that 20 ml is an extremely small amount of liquid.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student recognises that a milk bottle holds roughly '2 somethings' but writes 200 ml instead of 2 litres ‚Äî confusing the unit (thinks 200 ml ‚âà 2 litres, or does not know that 1 litre = 1,000 ml).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses the scale of millilitres and litres ‚Äî thinks 200 ml is a large amount, roughly equivalent to 2 litres.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student overestimates by a factor of 10. May confuse the size of a milk bottle with a large water container or have poor everyday reference points for litre quantities.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Overestimates by one order of magnitude ‚Äî lacks a practical benchmark for what 2 litres vs 20 litres looks like.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student has very poor sense of capacity scales ‚Äî 50 litres is roughly a quarter of a bathtub. This represents a wild overestimate showing no benchmark for litre measures.
distractor_analysis.misconception: No practical sense of litre scale ‚Äî does not recognise that 50 litres is an enormous amount of liquid.

metadata.knowledge_point: G9 ‚Äî Nets of 3D Shapes (cube net, identifying opposite faces)
metadata.visual: V1 ‚Äî Geometric figure (cube net on grid)

questions.question_text:
This net folds to make a cube.
Each face is labelled with a letter.

When the cube is folded, which letter will be on the face opposite P?
questions.diagram_description:
A cross-shaped cube net drawn on a square grid. The net consists of six unit squares arranged in a cross pattern:
  Row 1 (top): one square labelled 'P' in column 2
  Row 2 (middle): three squares in a horizontal row, labelled 'Q', 'R', 'S' in columns 1, 2, 3
  Row 3: one square labelled 'T' in column 2
  Row 4 (bottom): one square labelled 'U' in column 2
Each square is the same size. The face labelled 'P' is shaded light red to highlight it. The grid is visible behind the net. Letters are bold and centred in each face.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 220√ó320. Grid of 60px squares. Net centre at column 2. P at (60,0), Q at (0,60), R at (60,60), S at (120,60), T at (60,120), U at (60,180). Light grid, blue outlines, P shaded #fecaca, letters centred.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 220 310' width='220' height='310' font-family='Arial, sans-serif'><rect width='220' height='310' fill='#fff'/><g stroke='#d1d5db' stroke-width='0.5'><line x1='20' y1='20' x2='200' y2='20'/><line x1='20' y1='80' x2='200' y2='80'/><line x1='20' y1='140' x2='200' y2='140'/><line x1='20' y1='200' x2='200' y2='200'/><line x1='20' y1='260' x2='200' y2='260'/><line x1='20' y1='20' x2='20' y2='260'/><line x1='80' y1='20' x2='80' y2='260'/><line x1='140' y1='20' x2='140' y2='260'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='260'/></g><rect x='80' y='20' width='60' height='60' fill='#fecaca' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='110' y='60' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#991b1b'>P</text><rect x='20' y='80' width='60' height='60' fill='#dbeafe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='50' y='120' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>Q</text><rect x='80' y='80' width='60' height='60' fill='#dbeafe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='110' y='120' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>R</text><rect x='140' y='80' width='60' height='60' fill='#dbeafe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='170' y='120' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>S</text><rect x='80' y='140' width='60' height='60' fill='#dbeafe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='110' y='180' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>T</text><rect x='80' y='200' width='60' height='60' fill='#dbeafe' stroke='#1e40af' stroke-width='2'/><text x='110' y='240' text-anchor='middle' font-size='22' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>U</text><text x='110' y='290' text-anchor='middle' font-size='12' fill='#6b7280'>Net of a cube</text></svg>
questions.solution:
Fold the net with R as the base:
  P (above R) folds up ‚Üí back face
  Q (left of R) folds up ‚Üí left face
  S (right of R) folds up ‚Üí right face
  T (below R) folds up ‚Üí front face
  U (below T) folds further ‚Üí top face

Opposite face pairs:
  P ‚Üî T  (back ‚Üî front)
  Q ‚Üî S  (left ‚Üî right)
  R ‚Üî U  (bottom ‚Üî top)

The face opposite P is T.

Answer: T.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests spatial reasoning ‚Äî specifically the ability to mentally fold a 2D net into a 3D cube and determine which faces end up opposite each other. A correct answer shows the student can visualise the folding process and track face positions. Each distractor represents a different spatial misconception about how nets fold.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: The student must mentally simulate folding a cross net and track six faces to determine one specific opposite pair. This requires spatial visualisation at DOK2 (the student must choose a mental strategy for folding). The cross net is the most standard cube net, making this accessible at L2, but the opposite-face identification adds challenge (IPL3).
design_rationale.number_choice: N/A ‚Äî this is a spatial reasoning question, not a numerical calculation. The cross-shaped net was chosen because it is the most commonly tested net configuration in GL exams.
design_rationale.context_design: Cube net on a grid (V1) with clear letter labels. The grid supports counting squares and verifying the folding direction. P is highlighted (shaded red) to draw attention to the reference face. QF2 format with spatial context.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: Each wrong option represents a different face that the student might incorrectly believe is opposite P: B = furthest face in the net (D2); C = shares edge with P (D2); D = adjacent face (D2); E = mirror-position of Q (D2).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reasons that U is the 'furthest away' from P in the flat net, so it must be opposite when folded. In reality U ends up opposite R (the base), not P.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Believes the face furthest away in the 2D net will be opposite when folded ‚Äî confuses 2D distance in the net with 3D opposite-face relationship.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student sees that P shares an edge with R in the net and reasons that they will be 'facing each other' when folded. In reality they become adjacent faces (back and base), not opposite faces.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Believes faces that share an edge in the net will be opposite when folded ‚Äî confuses adjacency with opposition.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student sees that Q is on the left side of the middle row. Since P is above R and Q is beside R, the student may think they end up opposite. In reality Q (left face) is adjacent to P (back face).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Incorrectly tracks face positions during mental folding ‚Äî assigns the wrong final position to Q.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reasons that S is on the opposite side of the middle row from Q, and since P is above the centre, S might be opposite. In reality S (right face) is adjacent to P (back face), and Q ‚Üî S are actually opposite to each other.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses the Q-S opposite pair with a P-S pair ‚Äî misidentifies which pair of faces are opposite.

metadata.knowledge_point: A4 ‚Äî One-step Equations

questions.question_text:
Solve:

7n = 63
questions.solution:
7n means 7 √ó n.
To find n, divide both sides by 7:
  n = 63 √∑ 7 = 9.

Check: 7 √ó 9 = 63 ‚úì

Answer: 9.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can solve a one-step multiplication equation by applying the inverse operation (division). A correct answer shows the student understands that 7n means 7 √ó n and can isolate the variable using division. Each distractor reveals a different misconception about what the equation is asking or how to solve it.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Single inverse operation (63 √∑ 7). The student must (1) interpret 7n as multiplication and (2) apply division. Both are standard Y5 algebraic skills. Fits Apply √ó DOK1 at L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: 7n = 63 was chosen because (i) 63 √∑ 7 = 9 is within the times-table range, keeping arithmetic simple while testing algebraic understanding, (ii) 63 ‚àí 7 = 56 and 63 + 7 = 70 produce clean distractors from common wrong-operation errors, and (iii) 7 and 63 both appear as plausible answers for students who confuse the coefficient with the solution.
design_rationale.context_design: Pure equation (QF1) ‚Äî no word-problem wrapper. Tests algebraic notation directly.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: All four distractors are D2 (conceptual misconceptions about equations): A = subtracts (D2); B = gives coefficient (D2); C = adds (D2); E = gives RHS (D2).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 63 ‚àí 7 = 56. Uses subtraction instead of division as the inverse of multiplication.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Uses the wrong inverse operation ‚Äî subtracts instead of dividing to undo multiplication.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads '7n = 63' and gives 7 as the answer. Confuses the coefficient with the variable's value, thinking 'n is the 7 in front'.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses the coefficient (7) with the solution for n ‚Äî misunderstands what the equation is asking.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 63 + 7 = 70. Uses addition instead of division as the inverse of multiplication.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Uses the wrong inverse operation ‚Äî adds instead of dividing to undo multiplication.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student gives the right-hand side of the equation directly as the answer. Does not perform any operation ‚Äî treats '7n = 63' as meaning 'n = 63'.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the coefficient entirely ‚Äî reads the equation as 'n = 63' without dividing by 7.

metadata.knowledge_point: F3 ‚Äî Adding Fractions with Unlike Denominators

questions.question_text:
Work out:

2/3 + 1/4
questions.solution:
Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) of 3 and 4:
  LCD = 12

Convert each fraction:
  2/3 = 8/12
  1/4 = 3/12

Add:
  8/12 + 3/12 = 11/12.

Answer: 11/12.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can add two fractions with different denominators by finding a common denominator, converting both fractions, and adding the numerators. This is a fundamental fraction skill. A correct answer confirms procedural fluency with unlike-denominator addition. Each distractor targets a specific misconception about how fraction addition works.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Three sub-steps: find LCD, convert both fractions, add numerators. The LCD of 3 and 4 is 12 ‚Äî a familiar number but not immediately obvious. The student must manage the conversion (2/3 ‚Üí 8/12 and 1/4 ‚Üí 3/12) before adding. Fits Apply √ó DOK1 (complex procedure) at L2.
design_rationale.number_choice: 2/3 + 1/4 was chosen because (i) 3 and 4 are coprime, forcing the student to find LCD = 12 rather than one denominator dividing the other, (ii) the conversion multipliers (√ó4 and √ó3) are simple, keeping arithmetic manageable, (iii) the 'direct-add' trap (3/7) is the single most common fraction misconception and should be tested, and (iv) the correct answer (11/12) is close to 1, providing a quick reasonableness check.
design_rationale.context_design: Pure fraction calculation (QF1) ‚Äî directly tests the addition algorithm without contextual distractions.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: All four distractors are D2 (fraction addition misconceptions): A = direct add (D2); B = correct denominator but adds original numerators (D2); C = multiplies numerators (D2); D = correct numerator sum but wrong denominator (D2).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student adds numerators and denominators separately: (2+1)/(3+4) = 3/7. This is the classic 'direct addition' misconception ‚Äî the most common error in fraction addition.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Adds numerators together and denominators together ‚Äî does not understand that a common denominator is needed.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly finds the LCD (12) but then adds the original numerators without converting: (2+1)/12 = 3/12. Only converts the denominator, not the numerators.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Finds the common denominator but does not adjust the numerators ‚Äî adds the original numerators (2 and 1) over the LCD.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student multiplies the two fractions instead of adding them: 2/3 √ó 1/4 = 2/12 = 1/6. Confuses the addition algorithm with the multiplication algorithm.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Multiplies fractions instead of adding ‚Äî applies numerator √ó numerator and denominator √ó denominator when the operation is addition.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly converts the numerators (2/3 ‚Üí 8 and 1/4 ‚Üí 3, giving 8+3=11) but uses the sum of the original denominators (3+4=7) instead of the LCD. Gets the numerator right but the denominator wrong.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Correctly adjusts numerators using the LCD but then adds the original denominators instead of using the common denominator.

metadata.knowledge_point: N3 ‚Äî Negative Numbers (temperature context)
metadata.difficulty: L2 ‚Äî Standard (wave: appears in L3 zone)

questions.question_text:
The thermometer shows the temperature at 6 a.m.

By noon, the temperature has risen by 9¬∞C.

What is the temperature at noon?
questions.diagram_description: A vertical thermometer with a scale from ‚àí10¬∞C at the bottom to 15¬∞C at the top. Major tick marks are at every 5¬∞C (‚àí10, ‚àí5, 0, 5, 10, 15), each labelled. Minor tick marks at every 1¬∞C. The mercury (red column) is filled up to the ‚àí4¬∞C mark. A small horizontal arrow points to the ‚àí4¬∞C level from the right. The 0¬∞C line is slightly thicker and labelled in bold. The background is light blue to suggest cold weather.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 140√ó320. Vertical thermometer tube from y=280 (‚àí10¬∞C) to y=40 (15¬∞C). Scale: 1¬∞C = 9.6px. Mercury filled from bottom to y=241.6 (‚àí4¬∞C). Tick marks at every 9.6px (1¬∞C), longer ticks every 5¬∞C. Labels at ‚àí10, ‚àí5, 0, 5, 10, 15. Red mercury fill, grey tube outline.
questions.solution:
Temperature at 6 a.m. = ‚àí4¬∞C (read from thermometer)
The temperature rises by 9¬∞C.

‚àí4 + 9 = 5

Temperature at noon = 5¬∞C.

Answer: 5¬∞C.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can (1) read a negative temperature from a thermometer, and (2) add a positive change to a negative number. A correct answer shows the student can handle arithmetic crossing zero on the number line. Each distractor targets a specific negative-number misconception.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Two steps: read the thermometer (‚àí4¬∞C), then compute ‚àí4 + 9 = 5. The cross-zero calculation is the key challenge ‚Äî many students struggle with adding a positive to a negative. The thermometer (V5) provides a visual scaffold. Fits Apply √ó DOK1, appropriate for L2 as a wave item in the L3 zone.
design_rationale.number_choice: ‚àí4¬∞C and +9¬∞C were chosen because (i) the answer (5¬∞C) is positive, requiring the student to cross zero ‚Äî the critical conceptual hurdle, (ii) both numbers are small enough for mental arithmetic, (iii) 4 + 9 = 13 provides a clean distractor for students who ignore the sign, and (iv) ‚àí4 is clearly marked on the thermometer between ‚àí5 and 0.
design_rationale.context_design: Temperature change ‚Äî the most natural and familiar context for negative numbers for UK children. The thermometer (V5) is the data source (IS2) and also a visual aid for counting up from ‚àí4. QF2 word problem format.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = adds both as negatives (D2); B = correct; C = ignores negative sign (D2); D = sign error on result (D1); E = off-by-one (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes ‚àí4 ‚àí 9 = ‚àí13. Interprets 'risen by 9¬∞C' as subtracting 9 instead of adding 9, or treats both numbers as negative: ‚àí(4 + 9) = ‚àí13.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Subtracts when the temperature rises ‚Äî confuses 'rises' with 'falls', or adds the magnitudes but keeps the negative sign.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student ignores the negative sign on ‚àí4 and computes 4 + 9 = 13. Treats the starting temperature as +4¬∞C.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the negative sign ‚Äî reads ‚àí4 as 4, then adds 9 normally.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly computes the magnitude (9 ‚àí 4 = 5) but applies the wrong sign, writing ‚àí5 instead of +5. Assumes the result must be negative because the starting temperature was negative.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Applies the wrong sign to the result ‚Äî believes that starting from a negative temperature means the answer must also be negative.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student counts up 9 from ‚àí4 but makes an off-by-one error (counting ‚àí4 as the first step instead of the starting point): counts ‚àí4, ‚àí3, ‚àí2, ‚àí1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 = nine counts, landing on 4 instead of 5.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Off-by-one counting error ‚Äî includes the starting number in the count when it should be excluded ('fence-post error').

metadata.knowledge_point: F11 ‚Äî Fraction and Percentage Application (multi-step discount)

questions.question_text:
A jacket costs ¬£80.

On Monday, the shop reduces the price by 1/4.
On Tuesday, the shop takes a further 10% off the Monday price.

What is the price of the jacket on Tuesday?
questions.solution:
Step 1 ‚Äî Monday price:
  1/4 of ¬£80 = ¬£20
  Monday price = ¬£80 ‚àí ¬£20 = ¬£60

Step 2 ‚Äî Tuesday price:
  10% of ¬£60 = ¬£6
  Tuesday price = ¬£60 ‚àí ¬£6 = ¬£54.

Answer: ¬£54.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can apply two sequential discounts ‚Äî first a fraction reduction, then a percentage reduction ‚Äî to the same item. The critical insight is that the 10% on Tuesday is applied to the MONDAY price (¬£60), not the original price (¬£80). A correct answer shows the student can chain multi-step reductions and apply each to the correct base. This is the hallmark of L3: selecting and sequencing methods.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Four sub-steps: (1) find 1/4 of ¬£80, (2) subtract to get Monday price, (3) find 10% of the Monday price, (4) subtract again. The key difficulty is that Step 3 must use ¬£60 (not ¬£80) as the base. This dependency between steps elevates the question to Apply √ó DOK2 at L3.
design_rationale.number_choice: ¬£80, 1/4, and 10% were chosen because (i) 1/4 of ¬£80 = ¬£20 and 10% of ¬£60 = ¬£6 are both clean, keeping arithmetic manageable while the multi-step logic provides the challenge, (ii) applying 10% to the wrong base (¬£80 ‚Üí ¬£8) gives a different answer (¬£52), creating a clear diagnostic distractor, and (iii) all five options are distinct and plausible.
design_rationale.context_design: A jacket sale with two-stage discounts (QF11 multi-step instruction). This is a realistic shopping scenario that tests sequential reasoning. No visual needed (V0, IS1).
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = correct; B = total discount amount (D1); C = both discounts off original (D3); D = only Step 1 (D3); E = only Step 2 from original (D3).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates both discounts (¬£20 and ¬£6) but adds them together (¬£20 + ¬£6 = ¬£26) and gives the total discount as the answer instead of the final price.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Gives the total discount amount instead of the sale price ‚Äî forgets to subtract from the original price.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student applies BOTH discounts to the original price instead of chaining them: 1/4 of ¬£80 = ¬£20 and 10% of ¬£80 = ¬£8. Total discount = ¬£28. Price = ¬£80 ‚àí ¬£20 ‚àí ¬£8 = ¬£52.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Applies both discounts to the original price instead of applying the second discount to the already-reduced price. Does not understand that sequential discounts compound.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates the Monday price (¬£80 ‚àí ¬£20 = ¬£60) but stops here, presenting the intermediate result as the final answer. Forgets to apply the Tuesday discount.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Presents the intermediate result (Monday price) as the final answer ‚Äî only completes the first of two discount steps.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student skips the Monday discount entirely and only applies the Tuesday discount to the original price: 10% of ¬£80 = ¬£8, ¬£80 ‚àí ¬£8 = ¬£72.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the first discount (1/4 off) and only applies the second (10% off) to the original price.

metadata.knowledge_point: R3 ‚Äî Proportion / Scaling (recipe context)

questions.question_text:
Here is a recipe for pancakes that serves 4 people.

Emma wants to make pancakes for 6 people.

How much flour does she need?
questions.diagram_description:
A recipe card illustration on a cream-coloured background with a red border. The title reads 'Pancakes (Serves 4)' in bold. Below it, the ingredients are listed:
  300 g flour
  2 eggs
  200 ml milk
  50 g butter
The card has a small whisk icon in the top-right corner. No method is shown ‚Äî only the ingredients.
questions.diagram_specification: SVG 280√ó200. Rounded rectangle with cream fill #fef9ef, red border #dc2626, stroke-width 2. Title at top. Four ingredient lines left-aligned. Small decorative whisk icon top-right.
questions.svg: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 280 200' width='280' height='200' font-family='Arial, sans-serif'><rect x='5' y='5' width='270' height='190' rx='10' fill='#fefce8' stroke='#dc2626' stroke-width='2.5'/><text x='140' y='35' text-anchor='middle' font-size='16' font-weight='bold' fill='#991b1b'>Pancakes</text><text x='140' y='52' text-anchor='middle' font-size='12' fill='#92400e'>(Serves 4)</text><line x1='30' y1='60' x2='250' y2='60' stroke='#fbbf24' stroke-width='1'/><text x='35' y='85' font-size='14' fill='#333'>300 g flour</text><text x='35' y='108' font-size='14' fill='#333'>2 eggs</text><text x='35' y='131' font-size='14' fill='#333'>200 ml milk</text><text x='35' y='154' font-size='14' fill='#333'>50 g butter</text><g transform='translate(230,20) scale(0.5)' fill='none' stroke='#b45309' stroke-width='3' stroke-linecap='round'><line x1='15' y1='5' x2='15' y2='45'/><ellipse cx='15' cy='55' rx='12' ry='8'/><line x1='5' y1='20' x2='25' y2='20'/><line x1='5' y1='30' x2='25' y2='30'/></g></svg>
questions.solution:
The recipe serves 4 people. Emma needs to serve 6 people.

Method ‚Äî find the amount per person, then scale up:
  Flour per person = 300 g √∑ 4 = 75 g
  Flour for 6 people = 75 g √ó 6 = 450 g.

Alternative ‚Äî use a scale factor:
  Scale factor = 6 √∑ 4 = 1.5
  Flour = 300 √ó 1.5 = 450 g.

Answer: 450 g.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can scale a recipe ingredient proportionally from 4 servings to 6 servings. A correct answer shows the student can identify the scale factor (6/4 = 1.5 or use the unitary method: √∑4 then √ó6) and apply it to the correct ingredient. The recipe card contains multiple ingredients, testing whether the student extracts the right one (flour) and ignores the rest.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Three steps: (1) identify the relevant ingredient from the recipe, (2) determine the scale factor or use the unitary method, (3) calculate the scaled amount. The non-integer scale factor (1.5) is the main difficulty ‚Äî students cannot simply double or halve. The recipe context adds information-processing load (IPL3) because the student must select the right ingredient. Fits Apply √ó DOK2 at L3.
design_rationale.number_choice: 300 g flour for 4 people, scaling to 6 people, was chosen because (i) 300 √∑ 4 = 75 is clean, and 75 √ó 6 = 450 is also clean, (ii) the scale factor 1.5 is non-trivial but manageable (half as much again), (iii) 300 √ó 2 = 600 is a natural 'doubling' distractor for students who round 6 people up to 8 (= 2 √ó 4), and (iv) the recipe context with multiple ingredients tests data extraction.
design_rationale.context_design: Pancake recipe card (V7) ‚Äî a familiar, age-appropriate context. The recipe lists four ingredients but the question only asks about flour, requiring the student to filter relevant information. QF2 word problem format.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = reads wrong ingredient (D2); B = doubles instead of √ó1.5 (D3); C = correct; D = triples instead of √ó1.5 (D3); E = per-person amount (D1).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads the milk amount (200 ml) instead of the flour amount (300 g) from the recipe card, or applies the scale factor to the wrong ingredient. Gets 200 and misidentifies it as the answer for flour.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads the wrong ingredient from the recipe ‚Äî extracts 200 (milk) instead of 300 (flour), or confuses g with ml.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student doubles the flour amount: 300 √ó 2 = 600 g. Thinks that going from 4 to 6 people means doubling the recipe (scaling to 8 people instead of 6).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Uses doubling as the scaling strategy ‚Äî rounds up to the nearest multiple of the original serving size (4 ‚Üí 8) instead of calculating the exact scale factor for 6.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 300 √ó 6 = 1,800 then √∑ 2 = 900, or computes 300 √ó 6 √∑ 2 = 900 through a confused scaling process. Alternatively, the student computes 300 √ó 3 = 900 thinking '6 is 3 times something' (confusing √ó3 with the correct √ó1.5).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Uses the wrong scale factor ‚Äî multiplies by 3 (perhaps thinking 6 √∑ 2 = 3) instead of 1.5 (= 6 √∑ 4).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates the flour per person (300 √∑ 4 = 75 g) but gives this intermediate result as the final answer instead of multiplying by 6.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Presents the per-person intermediate result as the final answer ‚Äî completes Step 1 of the unitary method but omits Step 2.

metadata.knowledge_point: S7 ‚Äî Two-way Tables
metadata.information_source: IS3 ‚Äî Complex data source (multi-row, multi-column table)

questions.question_text:
The two-way table below shows the favourite sport of pupils in Year 5 and Year 6.
Some numbers are missing.

How many Year 5 pupils chose football?
questions.diagram_description:
A two-way table with 4 columns (Tennis, Football, Swimming, Total) and 3 rows (Year 5, Year 6, Total). Some cells contain numbers and some are empty (marked '?'). The table data is:
  Year 5:  Tennis=11, Football=?, Swimming=9, Total=?
  Year 6:  Tennis=?, Football=17, Swimming=15, Total=45
  Total:   Tennis=24, Football=?, Swimming=24, Total=75
The header row is shaded blue. The '?' cells have a light yellow background.

x1='10' y1='72' x2='410' y2='72' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><rect x='10' y='72' width='400' height='32' fill='#fff'/><text x='60' y='93' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'
