y2='104' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><rect x='10' y='104' width='400' height='32' fill='#f0f9ff'/><text x='60' y='125' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#1e3a5f'>Total</text><text x='160' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>24</text><rect x='200' y='106' width='80' height='28' fill='#fef9c3' rx='2'/><text x='240' y='125' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#92400e'>?</text><text x='320' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>24</text><text x='385' y='125' text-anchor='middle' fill='#333'>75</text><line x1='10' y1='136' x2='410' y2='136' stroke='#93c5fd' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='115' y1='10' x2='115' y2='136' stroke='#93c5fd' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='10' x2='200' y2='136' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><line x1='280' y1='10' x2='280' y2='136' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/><line x1='355' y1='10' x2='355' y2='136' stroke='#e2e8f0' stroke-width='0.5'/></svg>
questions.solution:
Step 1 ‚Äî Find the Year 5 total:
  Grand total = 75,  Year 6 total = 45
  Year 5 total = 75 ‚àí 45 = 30

Step 2 ‚Äî Find Year 5 football:
  Year 5 total = 30,  Year 5 tennis = 11,  Year 5 swimming = 9
  Year 5 football = 30 ‚àí 11 ‚àí 9 = 10.

Verification via column:
  Total football = 75 ‚àí 24 ‚àí 24 = 27
  Year 6 football = 17
  Year 5 football = 27 ‚àí 17 = 10 ‚úì

Answer: 10.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can navigate a two-way table with missing values and use row/column constraints to find an unknown. A correct answer requires a 2-step process: first derive the Year 5 total from the grand total, then subtract the known sports. This tests Analyse √ó DOK2 ‚Äî the student must plan which cells to compute first.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: The target cell (Year 5 Football) cannot be found directly ‚Äî the student must first compute Year 5 Total (= 75 ‚àí 45 = 30), then use it to find Football (= 30 ‚àí 11 ‚àí 9 = 10). Alternatively, the student can compute Total Football (= 75 ‚àí 24 ‚àí 24 = 27) then subtract Year 6 Football (= 27 ‚àí 17 = 10). Either path requires 2 dependent steps. This dependency elevates the question to L3.
design_rationale.number_choice: Numbers were chosen so that (i) the answer (10) is a clean round number, (ii) Year 5 total (30) and Football total (27) are both derivable and can be verified via two independent paths, (iii) Year 6 football (17) is present in the table, creating a 'wrong row' distractor, and (iv) all values are realistic for a school context.
design_rationale.context_design: Favourite sport survey ‚Äî familiar school context. The two-way table (V3) is the complex data source (IS3) with multiple missing values. QF2 word problem format requiring data extraction and multi-step reasoning.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = reads Year 6 football (D2, wrong row); B = Year 5 total intermediate result (D3); C = 24‚àí17 (D2, wrong column subtraction); E = correct.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student reads the Year 6 football value (17) instead of computing Year 5 football. Picks the number already visible in the football column without checking which row it belongs to.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads from the wrong row ‚Äî gives the Year 6 value when asked for Year 5.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly calculates Year 5 total (75 ‚àí 45 = 30) but presents this intermediate result as the answer instead of subtracting tennis and swimming.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Gives the row total (Year 5 total) instead of the specific cell ‚Äî stops at the intermediate result.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes 24 ‚àí 17 = 7, subtracting Year 6 football from the Tennis total. Mixes up columns ‚Äî uses the Tennis total (24) instead of the Football total (27).
distractor_analysis.misconception: Subtracts from the wrong column total ‚Äî uses Tennis total instead of Football total.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly computes Total Football (75 ‚àí 24 ‚àí 24 = 27) but gives this column total as the answer instead of subtracting Year 6 football (17) to find Year 5 football.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Gives the column total (all football) instead of the specific cell (Year 5 football) ‚Äî stops at an intermediate result.

metadata.knowledge_point: N7 ‚Äî BODMAS / Order of Operations (brackets and indices)

questions.question_text:
Work out:

5 √ó (3¬≤ ‚àí 4) + 7
questions.solution:
Apply BODMAS step by step:

  Step 1 ‚Äî Indices (inside the brackets): 3¬≤ = 9
  Step 2 ‚Äî Brackets: 9 ‚àí 4 = 5
  Step 3 ‚Äî Multiplication: 5 √ó 5 = 25
  Step 4 ‚Äî Addition: 25 + 7 = 32.

Answer: 32.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests full BODMAS understanding including brackets AND indices combined. A correct answer shows the student can handle all priority levels in the correct order: indices first (inside brackets), then brackets, then multiplication, then addition. Compared to Q18 (simple BODMAS), this adds index notation ‚Äî a significant step up to L3.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Four-step calculation with a decision at each step about what to evaluate next. The expression nests an index inside brackets, testing whether the student applies B-I-DM-AS in the right order. The multiplication happens to produce the same number as the bracket result (5 √ó 5), which could cause careless errors. Fits Apply √ó DOK2 at L3.
design_rationale.number_choice: 5 √ó (3¬≤ ‚àí 4) + 7 was chosen because (i) 3¬≤ = 9 is within recall range, (ii) 9 ‚àí 4 = 5 is clean, (iii) the coincidence 5 √ó 5 = 25 adds a subtle check on whether the student used the right 5 (the external multiplier vs the bracket result), (iv) all four wrong paths yield distinct clean integers, and (v) the correct answer (32) is not the largest or smallest option.
design_rationale.context_design: Pure calculation (QF1) ‚Äî directly tests BODMAS with indices. No context needed.
design_rationale.distractor_logic: All four distractors are D2 (BODMAS misconceptions): A = a√ón trap on 3¬≤; B = correct; C = ignores brackets; D = groups + before √ó; E = drops the multiplier.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student interprets 3¬≤ as 3 √ó 2 = 6. Then: 5 √ó (6 ‚àí 4) + 7 = 5 √ó 2 + 7 = 10 + 7 = 17.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Reads 3¬≤ as 3 √ó 2 = 6 instead of 3 √ó 3 = 9 ‚Äî the a√ón exponent misconception (same as Q22).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student ignores the brackets and applies BODMAS to the expression as if it were 5 √ó 3¬≤ ‚àí 4 + 7: first 3¬≤ = 9, then 5 √ó 9 = 45, then 45 ‚àí 4 + 7 = 48.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores brackets ‚Äî evaluates multiplication before the subtraction inside the brackets.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student correctly evaluates the bracket (3¬≤ ‚àí 4 = 5) but then groups the addition with the bracket before multiplying: 5 √ó (5 + 7) = 5 √ó 12 = 60.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Treats the +7 as if it were inside the brackets ‚Äî groups the addition with the bracket result before applying the multiplication.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student evaluates the bracket correctly (3¬≤ ‚àí 4 = 5) and adds 7 (= 12) but drops the 5√ó multiplier entirely. Computes (3¬≤ ‚àí 4) + 7 = 5 + 7 = 12.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the leading multiplier ‚Äî does not apply the 5√ó to the bracket result.

metadata.knowledge_point: M8 ‚Äî Compound Measures (Speed = Distance √∑ Time)

questions.question_text:
A car travels at a steady speed of 40 miles per hour.

How far does the car travel in 2 hours and 15 minutes?
questions.solution:
Step 1 ‚Äî Convert time to hours:
  15 minutes = 15/60 = 0.25 hours
  Total time = 2 + 0.25 = 2.25 hours

Step 2 ‚Äî Use the formula Distance = Speed √ó Time:
  Distance = 40 √ó 2.25 = 90 miles.

Alternative method:
  Distance in 2 hours = 40 √ó 2 = 80 miles
  Distance in 15 minutes = 40 √∑ 4 = 10 miles
  Total = 80 + 10 = 90 miles.

Answer: 90 miles.

design_rationale.assessment_objective: Tests whether the student can apply the speed-distance-time formula with a non-whole-number time that requires conversion from hours-and-minutes. A correct answer shows the student can (1) convert 15 minutes to a fraction/decimal of an hour, (2) select the correct formula, and (3) multiply accurately. The two D4 base-60 traps target the most common error in time-based calculations.
design_rationale.difficulty_composition: Three dependent steps: convert time, select formula, multiply. The 15-minute conversion (0.25 hours) is the key decision point ‚Äî students must know that 15 min = 1/4 hour, not 0.15 hours. This time-conversion step plus the formula application makes it Apply √ó DOK2 at L3.
design_rationale.number_choice: 40 mph and 2h15m were chosen because (i) 40 √ó 2.25 = 90 is a clean answer, (ii) the base-60 trap (40 √ó 2.15 = 86) also produces a clean integer, (iii) the 'half-hour confusion' trap (40 √ó 2.5 = 100) is clean, (iv) all distractors are plausible distances, and (v) 40 mph is a realistic and familiar speed for UK roads.
design_rationale.context_design: Car journey ‚Äî a standard speed-distance-time context. No visual needed; all data is in the text (V0, IS1). QF2 word problem format with IPL3 because the student must coordinate three pieces of information (speed, hours, minutes).
design_rationale.distractor_logic: A = ignores 15 minutes (D3); B = base-60 decimal trap (D4); C = 15 min = half hour (D2); E = adds raw minutes (D4).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student only uses the whole hours: 40 √ó 2 = 80, ignoring the 15 minutes entirely. Stops at the easy part of the calculation.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Ignores the fractional time ‚Äî only multiplies speed by the whole number of hours.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student converts 2 hours 15 minutes to 2.15 (treating minutes as a decimal fraction out of 100 rather than out of 60): 40 √ó 2.15 = 86.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Base-60/base-100 confusion ‚Äî treats 15 minutes as 0.15 hours instead of 0.25 hours (writes time as 2.15 instead of 2.25).

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student thinks 15 minutes = half an hour (0.5 hours) instead of quarter of an hour (0.25 hours): 40 √ó 2.5 = 100.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Confuses 15 minutes with 30 minutes ‚Äî thinks a quarter of an hour is half an hour.

distractor_analysis.generation_path: Student computes distance for 2 hours (40 √ó 2 = 80) and then adds the raw minute value: 80 + 15 = 95. Treats minutes as if they are miles.
distractor_analysis.misconception: Adds raw minutes to the distance ‚Äî treats the time unit (15 minutes) as a distance unit (15 miles), a fundamental unit-confusion error.

metadata.knowledge_point: G5 ‚Äî Coordinates (translation in the first quadrant)

questions.question_text:
Rectangle ABCD is drawn on the grid below.
  A = (1, 1)    B = (5, 1)    C = (5, 3)    D = (1, 3)

The rectangle is translated so that vertex A moves to (3, 4).

What are the new coordinates of vertex C?
questions.diagram_description: A first-quadrant coordinate grid from (0, 0) to (9, 8). Grid lines are drawn at every unit. The x-axis and y-axis are labelled with numbers 0‚Äì9 and 0‚Äì8 respectively. Rectangle ABCD is drawn with vertices at A(1,1), B(5,1), C(5,3), D(1,3), shaded light blue. Each vertex is marked with a dot and labelled A, B, C, D. An arrow shows the translation from A(1,1) to A'(3,4) as a dashed line.
